editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A Table Alphabeticall, contayning and teaching the true writing and vnderſtanding of hard vſuall Engliſh wordes, borrowed from the Hebrew, Greeke, Latine, or French, &c.
With the Interpretation thereof by plaine Engliſh words, gathered for the benefit and help of all vnskilfull perſons.

Whereby they may the more eaſily and better vnderſtand many hard Engliſh words, which they ſhall heare or read in Scriptures, Sermons, or elſe where, and alſo be made able to vſe the ſame aptly themſelues.
Set foorth by R. C. and newly corrected, and much inlarged by T. C.

q.p: As good not to read, as not to vnderſtand.

div.p: LONDON: Printed by T. S. for Edmund Weauer, and are to be ſold at his ſhop at the great North dore of Paules Church. 1609.

div.head: To the right honourable, Worſhipfull, vertuous, and godly Ladies, the Lady Haſtings, the Lady Dudley the Lady Mountague, the Lady Wingfield, and the Lady Leigh, his Chriſtian friends, R. C. wiſheth great proſperitie in this life, with increaſe of grace, and peace from God our Father, though Ieſus Chriſt our Lord and onely Sauiour.
div.p: BY this Table (right Houourable and Worſhipfull) ſtrangers that blame our tongue of difficultie, and vncertaintie, may hereby plainely ſee, and better vnderſtand thoſe things, which they haue thought hard. Hereby alſo the true Orthographie, that is, the true writing of many hard Engliſh words, borrowed from the Greeke, Latine and French, and how to know one from the other, with the interpretation thereof by plaine Engliſh words, may be learned & known. And children hereby may be prepared for the vnderſtanding of a great number of Latine words: which alſo will bring much delight and iudgement to others, by the vſe of this little worke.

Now when I had called to minde (right Honorable and Worſhipfull) the great kindnes, and bountifulneſſe, which I found in that vertuous and godly Lady, Lucy Harington, your Honors and Worſhips mother, and my eſpeciall friend in the Lord. When, and at ſuch time as the right Worſhipfull Sir Iames Harington Knight, your Ladiſhips Brother, was my Scholler (and now my ſingular benefactor) when I taught the Grammer Schoole at Okeham in the County of Rutland: In conſideration whereof, and alſo for that I acknowledge my ſelfe much beholding and indebted to the moſt of you, ſince this time, (being all naturall Siſters) I am bold to make you all ioyntly Patrons hereof, and vnder your names to publiſh this ſimple worke. And thus praying, that God of his vnſpeakeable mercies, will bleſſe both your Honours and Worſhips, I do with all good wiſhes to you all, with all yours, as to mine owne ſoule, humbly take my leaue.

closer.signed: Your Honours and Worſhips, euer ready in Chriſt Ieſus to be commanded, Robert Cawdrey.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
SVch as by their place and calling (but eſpecially Preachers) as haue occaſion to ſpeake publiquely before the ignorant people, are to bee admoniſhed, that they neuer affect any ſtrange inkhorne tearmes, but labour to ſpeake ſo as is commonly receiued, and ſo as the moſt ignorant may well vnderſtand them: neyther ſeeking to be ouer fine or curious, nor yet liuing ouer careleſſe, vſing their ſpeach as moſt men doe, and ordering their wits as the feweſt haue done. Some men ſeek ſo far for outlandiſh Engliſh, that they forget altogether their mothers language, ſo that if ſome of their mothers were aliue, they were not able to tell or vnderſtand what they ſay; and yet theſe fine Engliſh Clearkes will ſay they ſpeake in their mother tongue; but one might well charge them for counterfayting the Kings Engliſh. Alſo, ſome far iournied gentlemen, at their returne home, like as they loue to goe in forraine apparrell, ſo they will pouder their talke with ouer-ſea language. Hee that commeth lately out of France, will talke French Engliſh, and neuer
bluſh at the matter. Another chops in with Engliſh Italianated, and applyeth the Italian phraſe to our Engliſh ſpeaking, the which is as if an Orator, that profeſſeth to vtter his minde in plaine Latine, would needs ſpeake Poetrie, and far fetched colours of ſtrange antiquitie. Doth any wiſe man thinke, that wit reſteth in ſtrange words, or elſe ſtandeth it not in wholſome matter, and apt declaring of a mans minde? Doe wee not ſpeake, becauſe we would haue others to vnderſtand vs? or is not the tongue giuen for this end, that one might know what another meaneth? Therefore, either wee muſt make a difference of Engliſh, and ſay, ſome is learned Engliſh, and otherſome is rude Engliſh, or the one is Court talke, the other is Country-ſpeech, or elſe we muſt of neceſsitie baniſh all affected Rhetorique, and vſe altogether one manner of language. Thoſe therefore that will auoid this follie, and acquaint themſelues with the plaineſt and beſt kinde of ſpeach, muſt ſeeke from time to time ſuch wordes as are commonly receiued, & ſuch as properly may expreſſe in plaine manner, the whole conceit of their minde. And looke what words we beſt vnderſtand, and know what they meane, the
ſame ſhould ſooneſt be ſpoken, and firſt applyed, to the vtterance of our purpoſe. Therfore for this end, foure things would chiefly be obſerued in the choyſe of wordes. Firſt, that ſuch wordes as wee vſe, ſhould bee proper vnto the tongue wherein we ſpeake. Againe, that they be plaine for all men to perceiue. Thirdly, that they bee apt and meete, moſt properly to ſet out the matter. Fourthlie, that wordes tranſlated, from one ſignification to another, (called of the Grecians Tropes,) be vſed to beautifie the ſentence, as precious ſtones are ſet in a ring, to commend the gold. Now ſuch are thought apt wordes, that properly agree vnto that thing, which they ſignifie, and plainly expreſſe the nature of the ſame. Therefore, they that haue regard of their eſtimation and credite, doe warily ſpeake, & with choiſe, vtter words moſt apt for their purpoſe. In waightie cauſes, graue wordes are thought moſt needfull, that the greatneſſe of the matter, may the rather appeare, in the vehemencie of their talke. So likewiſe of other, like order muſt be taken. Albeit ſome, not onely doe not obſerue this kinde of aptneſſe, but alſo they fall into much fondnes, by vſing words out
of place and applying them to diuers matters, without all diſcretion.

If thou be deſirous (gentle Reader) rightly and readily to vnderſtand, and to profit by this Table, and ſuch like, then thou muſt learne the Alphabet, to wit, the order of the Letters as they ſtand, perfectly without booke, and where euery Letter ſtandeth: as (b) neere the beginning, (n) about the middeſt, and (t) toward the end. Now if the word, which thou art deſirous to finde, begin with (a) then looke in the beginning of this Table, but if with (v) looke towards the end. Again, if thy word begin with (ca) looke in the beginning of the Letter (c) but if with (cu) then looke toward the end of that Letter. And ſo of all the reſt, &c.

And further vnderſtand, that all ſuch words as are deriued and drawne from the Greeke, are noted with this letter (g.) And the french are marked thus (§) but ſuch words as are deriued from the Latine and others, haue no marke at all.

div.head: A Table Alphabeticall, contayning and teaching the true writing and vnderſtanding of hard vſuall Engliſh words, &c.

list.item: The French words haue this (§) before them.

list.head: A
list.item: § ABandon, caſt away, or yéelde, vp, to leaue or forſake.
§ abbeſſe, Abbateſſe, Miſtreſſe of a Nunnerie, comfor • ers of others.
aberration, a going aſſray, or wandering.
abbreuiat, § abbridge, to ſhorten, or make ſhort.
§ abbut, to lye vnto, or border vpon, as one lands end méets with another.
abecédarie, the order of the Letters, or hé • that vſeth them.
abdicate, put away, refuſe, or forſake.
abhorre, hate, diſpiſe or diſ daine.
abiect, baſe, caſt away in diſ daine.
§ aboliſh, abolited, make void, deſtroy, deface, or out of vſe.
abſtract, drawne away from another: a little booke or volume gathered out of a greater.
academie, an Vniuerſitie, as Cambridge, or Oxford.
academicke, of the fect or wife and learned men
accent, tune, the riſing or falling of the voice.
accept, to take liking of, or to entertaine willingly.
§ acceptance, an agréeing to ſome former act done before.
acceſſe, frée cōming to, or a way to a place.
acceſſary, partaker in the ſame thing.
accidentall, falling by chance, not by nature.
acclamation, ſhowting, giuing of approbation, or diſliking by crying out.
accommodate, to make fit too, or conuenient to the purpoſe.
§ accompliſh, finiſh, or make an end of.
§ achieue, to make an end off.
§ action, the forme of a ſuite.
actuall, in act, or ſhewing it ſelfe in déede.
adage, an old ſpéech, or prouerbe.
adhaerent, cleauing to, or taking part with.
adiunct, an accidentall qualitie, or any propertie, that is not a ſubſtance.
§ adiourne, deferre, or put off till another time.
adiure, make to ſweare, or to deny.
adminiſter, gouerne, ſerue, or order, or doe ſeruice vnto.
adminiſtrator, one that doth buſineſſe for an another.
admire, maruell at, or be in loue with.
admiſsion, receiuing, or leaue to enter into a place, acceſſe.
adopt, to take for his chiide, fréely to chooſe.
§ aduance, preferre, lift vp to honour.
§ aduertiſe, giue knowledge, aduiſe, or counſell.
aduocate, a ſpokeſman, atturney, or pleader.
aduouſion, patronage, or power to preſent, or giue a liuing.

list.head: Ae, ſee E.
list.item: affable, ready, and curteous in ſpéech, gracious in words.
affect, to deſire earneſtly, or to minde.
aggrauate, make more grieuous, and more heauy.
alarum, a ſound to the batteli.
alchymie, (g) the art of turning other mettals into gold.
algeates, euery way, or howeuer it be.
alienate, to eſtrange, or withdraw the mind or to make a thing another mans.
§ all haile, all health, God ſpéede.
allegorie, (gr) ſimilitude, a myſticall ſpéech, more then the bare letter.
allevate, aſſwage, or make more eaſie and •• ght.
alluſion, meaning and pointing to another matter then is ſpoken in words.
allude, to ſpeake one thing that hath reſemblance and reſpect to another.
alphabet, (g) order of letters in the croſſerow.
ambition, deſire of honour, or ſtriuing for preferment.
ambodexter, one ye playeth on both hands.
§ ambuſhment, priuie traine, lying ſecretly to trap by the way.
amiable, louely, or with a good grace.
anarchie, (gr) when the land is without 〈◊〉 prince, or gouernour.
anatomie, (g) cutting vp of the body.
anathema, (g) accurſed or giuen ouer to the diuell.

adnimaduerſion, noting, conſidering, or ma •
• ing.
anales, Chronicles of things from yéere 〈◊〉 yéere.
annex, to knit or ioyne together.
annihilate, make voyd, or bring to nothing.
anniuerſarie, a yéers time, or done and comming yearely.
anteceſſour, an aunceſtour, or predeceſſour that goeth, or liueth in the age or place before vs.
antichriſt (g) againſt, or contrary to Chriſt.
antipodes, (g) thoſe that goe with their féet oppoſite to ours.
antiquarie, a man ſkilled in, or a ſearcher of antiquities.
apocrypha, (g) not of authoritie, a thing hidden, whoſe originall is not knowne.
apologie, (g) defence, or excuſe by ſpeach.
apoſtle, (g) an ambaſſadour or one ſent.
apothegme, (g) ſhort wittie ſentence, or ſpéech.
§ appeale, to ſéeke to a higher Iudge.
appendix, hanging, or belonging to another thing.
appertinent, appurtenance, belonging vnto another thing.
applaude, to ſhew a liking of, as it were, by clapping of hands.
application, applying too, or reſorting too.
appropriate, to take, and kéepe to, and for himſelfe alone.
• able, that is or may bée tilled.
• biter, • bitratour, a Iudge in a controuerſie betwixt men.
dome by the peares and nobility.

•• rrerages, debt vnpaid, or things left vn
• one and duties comming behind.
•• rreſt, ſtay, or lay hold of.
•• ide, to pleaſe well, to content.
• ariue, •• uall, come to land, or approch.
artifice, ſkill, ſubtiltie, or a cunning péece of worke.
articulate, ioynted, ſet together, or to point out, and diſtinguiſh.
§ artillery, engines or inſtruments for war.
aſcend, goe vp, or climbe vp.
aſcribe, giue to, adde to, attribute vnto.
askew, anſquint, looking aſide, or awry.
aſpect, looking vpon, beholding much ſight
aſpectable, worthy, or eaſie to be ſéene.
aſpire, climbe vp, or labour to come to.
to ſet vpon, or to proue.
aſſertion, affirming, auonching of any thing
aſsimulate, to make like, to compare with.
aſtipulation, an auouching, or witneſſing of a thing, an agréement.
aſtrictiue, aſtringent, binding, or ioyning together.
aſtrolabe, (g) an inſtrument to know the motion of the ſtarres.
atheiſt, (g) atheall, without God, or beléeuing that there is no God, or denying any of his attributes.
atheiſme, (g) the opinion of the Atheiſt.
atomie, (g) a thing ſo ſmall that it cannot bée deuided.
§ attach, ſeaſe vpon, reſt, or hold.
§ attainder, a conuiction, or prouing guiltie of a crime or fault.
§ attempt, ſet vpon, or take in hand.
attendance, watching, ſtaying for, or way ting vpon.
attenuate, to make thinner or weaker, to leſſon.
atteſt, to witneſſe, or call to witneſſe.
auarice, couetousneſſe, or inordinate deſire of money.
audience, hearing, or hearkning, or thoſe that heare.
audacious, bold, raſh, or fooliſh hardie.
auditor, hearer, or officer of accounts.
§ auer, auouch, call to witneſſe, proue.
auert, to turne from, or kéepe away.
auguration, augure, gueſſing, or coniecturing at things to come.
§ avowable, that which may be allowed and affirmed.
auoke, to call from, or pull backe.
auricular, in the eare, playning to the eare.
auxiliarie, that come to help and aide.
authenticall, (g) of authoritie, allowed by authoritie: the originall.
axiome (g) a certaine principle, or generall ground of any Art.
• ay, euer, at any time, for euer.

list.head: B
list.item: BAinbate, beare or cary like a porter.
§ balaſe, grauell, wherewith ſhips are poyſed to goe vpright: or weight.
§ band, company of men, or an aſſembly.
barbariſme, rudeneſſe, a corrupt forme o • writing or ſpeaking.
barreſter, one allowed to giue counſell, o • to plead:
barreter, a contentious perſon, quarreller, or fighter.
bereft, depriued, alone, voyde, • o • d.
betrothed, affianced, or promiſed in mariage
§ biere, a cophin wherein dead men are carryed.
bigamie, (g) twiſe married, or hath had two wines.
bipar •• te, deuided into two parts.
blaſphemie, (g) to ſpeake ill of God.
§ bouge, ſtir, remoue from a place.
bourne, a water ſpringing out of the earth.
§ brandiſh, to ſhake, or caſt with • orce.
§ brigand, a théefe or robber by the high way ſide.
brothell, kéeper of a houſe of baudry.
bucolike (g) pertaining to beaſts or heardſmen.
buggerie, coniunction with one of the ſame kinde, or of men with beaſts.
bullyon, coyne or lumpe of ſiluer.
butte, border vpon, lye ouer againſt.
§ burgeſſe, a head man of a towne.
buxomneſſe, plyableneſſe, or humble ſtooping, in ſigne of obedience.

list.head: C
list.item: cadence, falling, properly the ledging of corne by a tempeſt.
calefie, make warme, heate or chaſe.
calumniation, a diſcrediting by word, or a falſe accuſation.
candidate, a ſui • er for, or one elect for a place
§ cancell, to vndoe, deſ ••• , croſſe out, or teare.
canoniſe (g) make a ſaint, to examin by rule.
capacitie, largeneſſe of a place, conceit or receit.
capitall, deadly, or great, or worthy of ſhame, and puniſhment.
capable, wiſe, apt to learne, bigge or fit to receiue.
capitulation, diſtinguiſhing by parts, bringing to heads.
captiuate, make ſubiect, or a priſoner.
§ carbonado, meat broyled on the coales.
carminate, to card wooll, or deuide.
carpe, take exception againſt, or wrangle.
§ caſſere, diſmiſſe, put away, or out of office
catalogue (g) beadrole, or rehearſall of words, or names.
cataſtrophe (g) the end of a thing, ouerthrow.
catechiſer (g) that teacheth the principles of Chriſtian religion.
catarre, a flowing of humours from the head.
cauill, to ieſt, ſcoffe, or reaſon ſubtilly.
caution, warning, putting in minde, or taking héede.
celebrate, holy, make famous, to publiſh, to to commend, to kéepe ſolemnely.
cenſor, a corrector, a iudge, or reformer of manners.
centre (g) middeſt of any round thing or circle.
centurion, captaine of an hundred men.
ceruſe, white leade, or painting that women vſe.
chaos (g) a confuſed heap or mingle mangle.
character (g) the faſhion of a letter, a marke or ſtampe.
§ champion, wilde field, alſo a challenger.
chambering, lightneſſe, and wanton behauiour in priuate places.
charter, a grant of any thing confirmed by ſeale.
chiromancie (g) telling of fortunes by the lines in the hand.
circumciſe, to cut the priuie ſkin.
circumference, the round and vtmoſt circuit or compaſſe.
circumſcribe, to compaſſe about with a line, to limit.
circumſpect, héedy, quick of ſight, wiſe, and doing matters aduiſedly.
circumlocution, a ſpeaking of that in many words, which may be ſaid in few.
circumſtance, a qualitie that accompanieth▪ any thing, as time place. &c.
circumſtant, things that are about vs.
circumuent, to cloſe in, to deceiue, or intrap craftily.
cite, alledge, call as witneſſe, to ſummon to appeare.
citadell, the fort of a towne.
ciuill, honeſt in conuerſation, or gentle in behauiour.
§ clame, title, right, challenge as his owne.
climate, a portion of the world betwix • North and South.
climactericall (g) that which ariſeth by degrées, as the ſixtie third yeare, is climactericall of ſeauentie, alſo dangerous.
coagulate, congeale, come to a curde.
caenation, ſupper, a place to ſup in.
collaterall, on the other ſide, ouer againſt, as two lines drawne equally diſtant one from another, in due place.
§ colonell, the Generall of an army.
columne, one ſide of a page of a booke.
cōbination, a ioyning, or coupling together.
combure, burne, or conſume with fire.
cōbuſtion, burning or conſuming with fire
comicall, handled merily like a comedy.
communicate, make pertaker, or giue part vnto.
§ communalitie, common people, or Common wealth.
compact, ioyned together, or an agréement.
competitor, hée that ſueth for the ſame thing, or office that another doth.
complexion, nature, conſtitution of the body.
compoſition, agréement, a making or mingling together.
compremiſe, agréement made by parties choſen on eyther ſide.
compu • gator, one that comes to purge or frée another.
concurre, agrée together, runne together or méete.
concurſe, running together of many to a place.
condole, to be grieued, or ſorrowfull with another.
confederate agréeing peaceably together by couenants made.
confine, to border vpon, to compaſſe in.
§ confiſcation, forfeiture or loſie of goods.
conforme, to make like vnto, conſent.
confound, ouerthrow, deſtroy, mingle together, or diſorder.
confront, oppoſe, compare one to another.
congeale, to harden, or wa • e hard, or fréeze together.
congratulate, to reioyce with another for ſome good fortune.
coniure, to conſpire together, to ſweare by.
conſanguinitie, kindred by blood, or birth.
conſecrate, make holy, to dedicate or giue vnto.
conſectarie, that followeth vpon any other thing.
conſociate, company with, or ioyne a companion vnto
conſpicuous, eaſie to bée ſéene, excellent.
conſpire, agrée together for to doe euill.
conſul, a chiefe gouernour among the Romanes.
contagious, that which corrupteth, or infecteth.
contemptible, worthy to be deſpiſed, not to be ſet by.
context, the agréeing of the matter going before, with that which followeth.
continent, modeſt, abſtaining, chaſt: alſo the firme land where no ile or ſea is.
contract, make ſhort, alſo a bargaine, or couenant.
contribute, beſtow vpon, or giue vnto.
contribution, a beſtowing of any thing with others.
contributorie, giuing his part to any thing.
conuexe, h • llow, binding downe on euery ſide.
conuince, to ouercome, confute, or proue manifeſtly.
conuocation, an aſſembling, or calling together.
§ conuoy, a waiting vpon, or kéeping company in the way.
connulſion, a pulling, or ſhrinking vp.
cophin (g) baſket, or cheſt for a dead body to be put in.
§ corriuals, competitors, louers of, or • uers for the ſame thing.
corpulent, groſſe of body, fat, or great.
correllatiues, when two things are ſo linked together, that the one cannot be without the other.
corroborate, confirme, or ſtrengthen, or make ſtrong.
§ correlarie, ouerplus, that is more then meaſure.
§ counterfaite, make like, ſéeme that it is not
§ countermure, to build one wall againſt another.
§ counterpoiſe, make leuell, or to weigh as heauie as another thing.
§ counterſcarpe, a rampire to a wall.
creditor, he which lendeth, or truſteth another.
criminous, criminall, faultie, that wherein is ſome fault.
criticall (g) which giueth iudgement of ſickneſſe, &c.
crude, raw, not ripe, not diſgeſted.
chryſtaline (g) cléere as glaſſe or chriſtall.
cubite, a foote and a halfe.
cunne, to diſcerne, alſo to giue.
cunſtable, the ſtay and ſupport of the king.

curioſitie, picked diligence, greater carefulnes,
then is ſéemely or neceſſarie.
cymball, an inſtrument of muſick, ſo called.
cypher (g) a circle in numbering, of no value of it ſelfe, but ſerueth to make vp the number, and to make other figures of more value.

list.head: D
list.item: decacordon (g) an inſtrument with tenne ſtrings.
deceaſe, a departing, or giuing place too.
decide, to determine, or make an end of.
decipher, deſcribe, or open the meaning, or to count.
declamation, an oration of a matter feyned.
decline, fall away, or ſwarue from.
decoction, liquor, wherein things are ſod for phiſicke.
deduct, take or draw out, abate, or diminiſh.
§ deface, blot out, ſtain, bring out of faſhion.
defame, to ſlaunder, or ſpeake ill of.
deferre, put off till another time.
define, to ſhew clearely what a thing is.
degenerate, be vnlike his aunceſtours: to grow out of kinde.
dehort, moue or perſwade from, to aduiſe to the contrary.
delegate, an embaſſadour, or one appointed in anothers place.
delineate, to draw the proportion of any thing.
delude, deceiue, or laugh to ſcorne.
§ deluge, great floode, or ouerflowing of waters.
democracie (g) a common-wealth gouerned by the people.
demonſtrate, ſhew plainly or openly, to point out or manifeſt.
§ demurre, to ſtay, to linger or vſe delayes.
denounce, declare, or giue warning of, or proclaime.
deplume, to pull off the feathers.
depoſe, put away, depriue, or put downe.
depraue, marre or corrupt, or make worſe.
deprecation, ſupplication, or requiring of pardon.
de • ide, mocke, or laugh to ſcorne.
depriuation, taking away from ſome other matter.
derogate, to take away, or to deminiſh.
deſcant, variation of the ground of a ſong.
deſcribe, to write forth, to coppy out, or to declare.
§ deſeigne, § deſeignement, an appointing how any thing ſhall be done.
deſigne, to marke out, or appoynt for any purpoſe.
deſperate, without hope, or paſt hope.

deſpume,
• ome, or caſt vp a ſcumme.
detract, take from, or backbi • e.
deuote, to giue vnto, to appoint vnto.
diapaſon (g) a concorde in Muſicke of all parts.
dialect (g) the manner of ſpeach in any language, diuers from others.
diameter (g) a •• ne croſſing the midſt of any circle or figure.
didacticall (g) full of doctrine or inſtruction.
diffamation, a ſlaundering, or ſpeaking ill of.
digeſt, bring into order, to deuide, & deſtribute things into their right place.
digreſsion, departing from the matter in hand.
dilapidation, waſtefull, ſpending, or ſuffering to goe to decay.
dilate, enlarge, ſpread abroad, or to diſcourſe vpon largely.
dilemma, (g) a forked kinde of argument, which on either ſide entrappeth.
diminiſh, make leſſe or take from.
direct, guide or rule: right, ſtraight, alſo to order.
diſable, make vnable, or finde fault with.
diſanull, make voyde, or bring to nothing.
diſcerne, know, put one for another, or put difference.
diſcide, cut off, or in péeces.
diſcipher, to lay open, or make plaine.
§ diſcouraged, made afraide, or out of hart.
diſcretion, wiſe choiſe of one from another.
diſcuſſe, examine, debate, or ſearch narrowly into.
diſgorge, ſpue v • , caſt out of the ſtomacke.
diſgrade, to diſcharge of his orders, or degrées.
§ diſguiſed, counterfaited, ſéeming that it is not.
diſlocation, ſetting out of right place.
§ diſloyall, one whom it is not good to truſt, vntruſty, traylerous.
§ diſmember, to pull and part one péece from another.
diſpenſe, to giue licence vnto, alſo charges, coſt.
diſplant, to pull vp by the rootes.
diſpoſe, to ſet in order, to appoint.
diſpoſition, naturall inclination, or ſetting in order.
diſpoyle, take away by violence, or rob.
diſputable, queſtionable, or doubtfull, that may be reaſoned of.
diſſent, diſagrée, to be of a contrarie opinion.
diſtemperature, beſides the meane, or due proportion.
diſtended, ſtretched out, or out of ioynt.
diſtick (g) a double méeter, or two verſes of one matter.
diſtinguiſh, put difference, deuide, or point out from others.
diſtillation, diſtilling, dropping downe by little and little.
diſtracted, diſtraught, drawne into diuers parts, alſo out of his wits.
diſtribute, deuide in ſunder, or to giue in ſundry parts.
diſtribution, diuiſion, or laying out by parts.
diſſwade, to perſwade to the contrary.
dittie, the matter of a ſong.
diuine, heauenly, godly, alſo to geſſe, coniecture, or propheſie.
diurnall, daily, belonging to the day.
diuulge, diuulgate. publiſh, or make common.
domeſticall, at home, belonging to houſhold.
dominion, domination, rule, lordſhip, or maiſterſhip.
donatiue, a gift, in monie or other things.
§ doſe, the quantitie of medicine the Phiſition appointeth.
droope, fainte, hange the head or wings.
duarchy, the equall raigne of two princes together.
duplicitie, double kinde of a thing.
durable, long laſting, or of long continuance.

list.head: E
list.item: eclipſe (g) failing of the light of the Sunne or Moone.
eccho, a ſound, reſounding back againe.
edict, a commaundement from authoritie, a proclamation.
edifie, to inſtruct, or builde vp in knowledge.
effect, a thing done, or to bring to paſſe.
egeſt, to caſt, or carry forth.
element, the firſt principle or beginning of any thing.
elevate, litt vp, or heaue vp.
§ embark, imbark, to ſhip a thing, or load a ſhip.
emblem (g) a picture ſhadowing out ſome thing to be learned.
eminent, appearing higher, or further out, excelling.
emperick (g) he that hath all his ſkill in phiſicke by practiſe.
emulatiou, enuie, in •• t • tion, deſire to excéed another.
enigmatical (g) ful of hard queſtiōs, obſcure.
encounter, ſet againſt, or to méete.
§ enchrochment, when the Lord hath gotten and ſeiſed of more rent or ſeruices of his tenant then of right is due.

§ endoffe,
•• t on the back, or write on y• back
§ enhaunce, to lift vp, or make greater.
§ enlarge, make bigger, ſet at libertie.
§ entrals, inward parts, as hart, liuer, &c.
§ enuiron, to encloſe, or compaſſe about.
epigram (g) a ſentence written vpon any for praiſe or diſpraiſe.
epitaph (g) the writing on a tombe or grane.
epithite (g) a name or title giuen to any thing.
epitome (g) the briefe copie of a booke, &c.
epitomiſe (g) to make an epitome, or to bring a ••• ke 〈◊〉 a le •• er volume.
equinoctium, when the dayes and nights are equall.
eradicate, pull vp by the rootes.
erect, ſet vp, or lift vp.
ermite (g) one dwelling in the wilderneſſe.
erronious, full of errour, and wandring out of the right way.
§ eſſay, tryall what one can ſay, or doe in any matter.
§ eſſoine, excuſe for any cauſe, delay.
eſtimate, eſtéeme, value, or priſe, thinke or iudge.
euacuated, made voyde, cleane taken away, or emptied.
euangell (g) the Goſpell or glad tydings.
euent, chaunce, or that which followeth any thing.
euchariſt (g) a thankſgiuing, the Lords ſupper.
euitable, that may be ſhunned or auoyded.
euident, eaſie to bée ſéene, playne.
exact, perfectly done, or to require with extremitie.
exaggerate, heape vpon, amplifie, to make a thing more then it is.
exanimate, make afraide, or trouble in minde.
exaſperate, whet on, to vexe, or make more angry.
exceſsiue, too much, more then inough.
exclude, thruſt, or ſhut out, or kéepe out.
excogitate, to muſe, or deuiſe exactly.
excommunicate, to thruſt out of company, or fellowſhip.
excrement, dung, offall, refuſe, or dregs.
excurſion, a ſkirmiſh in warres of ſome few running from their company.
execute, performe, or exerciſe ſome charge.
exemplifie, enlarge, or declare by examples.
exhalation, a breath or ſu •• e riſing vpward.
exhibite, put vp or beſtow, to offer, or ſet abroad for all men to ſée.
exorbitant, out of order, meaſure or place.
exoticke, outlandiſh, brought out of another country.
expell, put out, or thruſt out.
expence, coſt, or monie laid out.
expiation, pacifying with ſatiſfaction, purging by ſacrifice.
expire, to dye, or giue vp the ghoſt, to decay.
explane, to make manifeſt, or declare,
expoſe, to offer, or lay open, to hazard.
expoſtulate, to reaſon, or chide with, to complaine.
exprobration, vpbrayding, caſting in ones téeth.
expugnable, to be wonne or ouercome
expulſe, driue out, or thruſt out.
extant, appearing abroad, ſhewing it ſelfe.
extemporall, extempore, ſuddaine, without premeditation, or ſtudy.
extende, ſpread forth, prolong, or make longer, to inlarge.
extenuate, leſſen, •• iniſh, or make leſſe.
extirpate, to pull vp by the rootes.
extoll, aduance, or praiſe highly, to lift vp.
extort, to wring out, to wreſt from by violence.
extraordinarie, beſides, or more then common cuſtome.
exult, bragge, triumph, or leape for ioy.
exulcerate, to make ſore, or corrupt.

list.head: F
list.item: fabulous, fained, counterſaited, much talked of.
faction, deuiſion of people into ſundry parts and opinions.
factor, one that doth buſineſſe for another.
falſifie, to forge, to forge, to counterſait.
faſcinate, to bewitch, or diſfigure by inchantment.
§ faſchious, grieuous, or inducing to anger.
fatall, mortall, appointed by God to com • to paſſe.
§ female, feminine, the ſhée in mankinde, or other creatures.
feſtiuall, merry, pertaining to holy dayes.
figment, fiction, a lye, or tale.
figuratiue, to ſhavow, or repreſent, or to counterfaite.
filiall, like, or belonging to a ſonne.
finite, hauing an end, and certaine limits.
§ flagon, great wine cup, or bottle.
flexible, eaſily bent, pliant, or mutable.
fluxible, thin and running eaſily downe like water.
fomentation, an aſſ waging, or comforting by warmth.
forrage, fodder, alſo to prouide meate.
fragments, reliques, broken meates, péeces broken off.
fraudulent, deceitfull, craftie, or ful of guile.
frequent, often, done many times, ordinarie, much haunted, or goe too.
friuolous, vaine, trifling, of no eſtimation.
§ frounce, wrinckle, put out of order.
fructifie, to make fruitfull, or bring foorth much fruit.
function, calling, or charge, or trade, and place wherein a man liueth.
funerall, buriall, mourning, pertayning to a buriall, or mourning.
§ furbuſh, to dreſſe or ſcoure, or make clean.
§ furniture, all things neceſſary to vſe.
future, that which ſhall bée héereafter.

list.head: G
list.item: § gardian, a kéeper, defender, or tutor.
gargariſe, to waſh the mouth, and throate within, by ſtirring ſome liquor vp and downe in the mouth.
§ garniſh, trime, deck vp, make fine.
genealogie (g) generation, or a deſcribing of the ſtocke or pedegrée.
genius, the Angell that waits on man, be it a good or euill angell.
geographie (g) the deſcribing of the earth.
geometrie (g) art of meaſuring the earth.
geomancie (g) ſorcerie by circles and pricks in the earth.
germane, come of the ſame ſtocke.
geſticulate, vſe much or fooliſh geſture.
geſts, things done, or noble acts of princes.
glorifie, to giue honour, praiſe and commendation to any body.
gloſſe (g) a tongue, or expoſition of a darke ſpeech.
glutinate, to glue, or ioyne together.
gnomen (g) the ſtile, or cock of a diall.
gradation, ſteps, by little and little.
graduate, that hath taken a degrée.
gratifie, to pleaſure, or doe a good turne in way of thankfulneſſe.
gratulate, to bée glad for anothers ſake.
greciſme, the cuſtome of the Grecians.

list.head: H
list.item: HAbilitie, •• bilitie, ableneſſe or ſuffi • iencie.
habitable, that may bée dwelt in.
harmonie (g) agréement of diuers ſounds in muſicke.
hecticke (g) inflaming the hart, and ſoundeſt parts of the body.
hemiſphere (g) halfe of the compaſſe of heauen, that we ſée.
heriditarie, comming by inheritance, or ſucceſſion.
heriticall (g) hereticke (g) one that maintayneth hereſies.
heroicall (g) beſéeming a noble man, or magnificent.
hierarchie (g) the gouernment of prieſts, or holy gouernance.
hymne (g) kinde of ſong to the praiſe of God.
hipocrite (g) ſuch a one as in his outward apparell, countenaunce, and behauiour, pretendeth to bée another man then hée is indéede, or a deceiuer.
§ homicide, a man killer, or the killing of a man.
hononimie (g) when diuers things are ſignified by one word.
horizon (g) a circle deuiding the halfe of the firmament, from the other half which wée ſée not.
hoſpitalitie, good entertainment for friends and ſtrangers.
hoſtilitie, hatred, enmitie, or open wars.
humane, belonging to man, gentle, curteous, bounteous.
huſh, huſht, peace, or be ſtill.
hyperbolicall (g) beyond all credite, or likelihoode of truth.

list.head: I
list.item: idiome (g) a proper forme of ſpéech,
ignoble, of low and baſe birth.
illuſtrate, to make plaine, to declare.
illuminate, to enlighten, or make plaine.
immature, vnripe, or out of ſeaſon.
immanitie, beaſtly crueltie, or hugeneſſe and greatneſſe.
immediate, next to, not hauing any other betwixt.
imminent, at hand, ready to come vpon.
immoderate, without meaſure, excéeding great, or exceſſiue.
immunitie, fréedome from any thing, or libertie.
immure, to ſhut vp, or incloſe within wals.
immutable, conſtant, ſtill the ſame, vnchangable.
§ impart to make partaker of, to tell to.
impenetrable, that cannot be pierced, or entred into.
imperiou • , deſiring of rule, full of commanding, ſtately.
impertinent, not pertaining to the matter.
implacable, that cannot be pleaſed or pacified.
imply, to ſignifie, or make manifeſt.
implume, to pull off the feathers.
impoſe, lay vpon, or put on
importunate, requiring earneſtly, without being ſatiſfied, till the requeſt be obteyned.
imprecation, curſing or wiſhing euill vnto.
§ impregnable, vnuanquiſhed, not able to be ouercome, ſtrong.
impropriation, a thing accounted proper, which is not indéede.
improuident, careleſſe, not foreſéeing, or taking héede before hand.
impunitie, lack, or omiſſion of puniſhment.
impute, reckon, or aſſigne, blame, or to lay to ones charge.
inabilite, want of power or abilitie.
inaugurate, to aſke counſell of ſoothſaiers.
incarnate, taking fleſh vpon him, or to bring fleſh vpon.
incenſe, kinde of offering made by fire.
incend, kindle, burne, vexe, or chaſe, to incenſe, to ſtirre vp, or to ſet on fire, or to anger.
inceſt, vnlawfull copulation of man and woman within the degrées of kinred, or alliance, forbidden by gods law, whether it bée in marriage or otherwiſe.
inciſion, cutting or ſearching of a wound.
include, to ſhut in, or containe within.
incommunicable, that cannot bée imparted to any other, or proper to one perſon, and none other.
incomparable, that hath not his like.
incomprehenſible, that cannot be conceiued or vnderſtood.
incontinently, preſently, diſorderly or without moderation.
incredible, marueilous, ſuch as cannot bée beléeued.

incorporate, to graft one thing into the body
of another, to make one body or ſubſtance of two or moe, to mixe or put together.
incorruptible, vncorruptible, vnperiſhable, or not ſubiect to corruption.
inculcate, to vrge or repeate one thing often.
incurable, paſt cure, a wound that cannot bée healed.
indefinite, without rule or order, not determined.
indignitie, vnworthineſſe, vnſéemely vſage, infamie or diſgrace.
indiſſeluble, that cannot bée vnlooſed or vndone.
§ ind • te, to ſignifie, or giue in ones name.
indiuiſible, indiuiduall, that cannot be deuided or parted.
induce, to moue vnto, or allure, or draw.
indulgence, ſufferance, too gentle intreating, alſo pardon.
ineffable, vnſpeakable, y• cannot be vttered
ineſtimable, that cannot be valued, or accounted of as it deſerueth.
inexorable, that cannot, or will not be intreated.
infamous, ill reported of, or defamed.
§ infanterie, the footemen of an armie.
inferre, bring in, to alleadge or ſignifie.
inflamation, inflaming, or ſetting on fire.
inflexible, that cannot be bended, vnruly.
influence, a flowing in, alſo vertue,
informe, giue notice, to teach, to beginne to inſtruct.
infringe, to breake, to make weake, or féeble.
infuſe, to poure in, or ſ • éepe in,
§ ingage, lay to pledge, binde himſelfe.
ingeminate, double, make twiſe ſo much.
ingenerate, bred, or grafted in naturally.
ingine, engine, an inſtrument to doe any thing with.
ingot, a wedge of gold, alſo the trough wherin it is molten.
inhabitable, that cannot be dwelt in.
initiate, to begin, inſtruct, or enter into.
innauigable, that cannot be failed vpon.
inquiſitiue, deſirous, and diligent to finde out by aſking.
inſatiable, that cannot bée filled or contented
inſcription, a title or note written vpon any place.
inſcrutable, that cannot be ſearched into, or throughly knowne.
inſenſible, that cannot be felt or perceiued.
inſert, to put in, or graft in.
inſinuate, créepe into ones fauour cra • tily, alſo to ſignifie.
inſociable, that will not kéepe company.
§ inſtall, admit to a place of office, or honor.
inſtill, to put in, or drop in.
inſtitute, appoynt, ordaine, begin, or go in hand with.
inſult, to triumph, or vaunt ouer.
inſupportable, not able to be borne.
intemperate, without meaſure or meane, vnmodeſt in behauiour.
interceſsion, going betwéene, or making intreatie for another.
intercourſe, mutuall acceſſe, or paſſage one to another.
§ intereſt, loane, right, alſo a part in any thing.
interline, draw a line betwixt, or to blot out with a penne, and to write betwixt.
intermingle, mixe or mingle with, or amongſt.
intermiſsion, foreſlowing, a pawſing or breaking of.
interprete, open, make plaine, to ſhew the ſenſe and meaning of a thing.
inteſtiue, that which is at home, or belongeth to the inward parts.
inteſtate, that dyeth without making a will
§ intituled, called, noted, written on the beginning.
intricate, in wrapped, doubtfull, hard to be knowne.
intrude, to thruſt ones ſelfe into the company of others, or enter in violently.
inuade, to ſet vpon, to lay hold on.
inueigle, intice, or deceiue by ſubtiltie, to intrap.
inuerſion, turning vpſide downe, turning contrariwiſe.
§ inueſt, to ador • e, or decke, or grace.
inueterate, of long continuance, growne in cuſtome.
inuiſible, that cannot be ſéene or perceiued.
invocation, a calling vpon any thing with truſt in the ſame.
inure, to make plyable, or acquaint with.
irregular, out of rule or order.
irreuocable, not to be recalled, or not to be withdrawne.
§ iſſue, euent, or ſucceſſe, or end.
iterate, to repeat, or doe a thing often, or againe.
iubile, yéere of ioy, which hapned to the Iewes euery fittie yéere.
iudaiſme, worſhipping one God without Chriſt.
iudicious, that hath a good iudgement or vnderſtanding.
iuriſdiction, authoritie, to make, or execute lawes in any place.
iuſtifie, approue, or make to bée accounted good and iuſt.
iuſtified, made or accounted for righteous, cleane.

list.head: L
list.item: LAborinth, a place ſo full of windings and turnings, that a man cannot finde the way out of it.
languiſhing, pi • ing, conſuming, wearing away with grie • e or ſickneſſe.
lapidarie, one ſkilfull in precious ſtones or iewels.
laund, a plaine place betwixe trées.
laureate, crowned with Lawrell, or wearing a garland of Bayes.
§ league, agréement, or couenant of peace.
§ legacie, a gift by will, or an ambaſſage.
§ legeirdemaine, lighthandedneſſe, cra • tie flights, and conueiance.

legion,
• oſt. or band of ſouldiers.
legitimate, lawfull, according to law, and good order.
lenitiue. that eaſeth or all wageth paine,
lethargie (g) (k) a drowſie and forgetfull diſeaſe.
libertine, looſe in religion, one that thinkes hée may doe what hée liſteth.
librarie, a ſtudie, a great number of bookes.
licentious, taking libertie to doe euill.
ligament, the ſtring tying the bones together.
limaile, duſt that commeth of ſeling.
imitation, appointment, how • arre any thing ſhall goe, 〈…〉 yning.
limit, bounds, border, or land marke, alſo to ſet ſuch bounds, &c.
liniament, a forme, or proportion by lines, that are • rawne.
lineall, direct, in a right line.
lollar, a breaker of faſting dayes.
lunatick, wanting his wits, at a certaine time of the age of the Moone.
lumpiſh, ſad or ſ • w •• countenance.
luxurious, riotous, and exceſſiue in pleaſure and wantonneſſe.

list.head: M
list.item: MAcerate, to ſ • éepe in water, or make leane, alſo to diſquiet.
magnifie, to •• toll or praiſe highly.
maieſtie, the ſtately port and honorable renowne of any.
malediction, ſtaundering, ill report, or backbiting, or curſing.
§ maligne, to hate with purpoſe to hurt.
manicle, a ſetter for to binde the hands.
manumiſie, to ſet frée, or at libertie.
§ marche, goe in aray, or goe forward.
margent, edge, or brim of any thing.
martiall, warlike, or valiant, or taking pains and delight in wars.
martyre (g) witnes, one ſuffering death for the faith of Chriſt.
materiall, of ſome matter, or importance.
matron, an auncient, ſober, and diſcréete woman.
maxime, a principle, or ſure ground in any matter.
media • our, aduocate, or ſurety, or one making peace betwixt two.
meditation, the earneſt minding or thinking vpon a thing.
melancholie (g) blacke choler, a humour of ſolitarineſſe, or ſadneſſe.
mellifluous, ſwéet as hony, yéelding much hony.
melody (g) ſwéet ſounding, or ſwéet muſicke.
mercinary, ſeruing for wages, an hireling.
meritorious, that deſerueth, or ſet for aduantage.
metamorphoſis (g) a changing of one ſhape or likeneſſe into another.
metaphor (g) ſimilitude, or the putting ouer of a word from his proper and naturall ſignification, to a forraine or vnproper ſignification.
meteors (g) elementarie bodies, or moyſt things, ingendered of vapours in the aire aboue.
method (g) an order, or ready way to teach, or doe any thing.
militant, warring, or being in warres.
miniſtration, miniſtring, or ſeruice, or charge to doe a thing.
minoritie, a mans time vnder age.
§ miſpriſsion, concealement of a mans own knowledge.
misknow, is miſtate purpoſely, to be ignorant of.
mitigate, aſſwage, qualifie, or pa • i • e.
mixion, mixture, mingling, or tempering together.
moderate, temperate or kéeping a meane.
moderation, kéeping due order and proportion.
momentanie, that which laſteth but a while.
moment, weight or importance, alſo a ſhort time.
monarch (g) one ruling all the kingdomes about him.
monarchie (g) the rule of one prince alone.
monopolie (g) a licence that none ſhall buy and ſell a thing but one alone.
monument, a remembrance of ſome notable act, as tombs.
§ moote, argue, or diſpute a caſe in law.
morall, pertaining to manners, behauiour, and life among men.
mortall, that endeth, hauing an end, and dying, deadly.
mortifie, kill, or make dead, and ſenceleſſe.
mortuarie, dutie paid for the dead.
motiue, cauſe mouing, or the thing, and reaſon, that moueth to doe any thing.
§ moultre, make ſmall, turne to duſt.
§ mulct, a fine, penalty, or puniſhment.
multiplicitie, varietie, or diuerſitie of ſorts.
munition, defence, ſupportation, or ſtrength and plentie of weapons, to reſiſt in war.
municipall, priuately belonging to a fréeman, or burgeſſe of a cittie.
muſicall, that loueth or hath ſkill muſicke.
§ muſtaches, the ha • re of the vpper lippe.
muſter, take view of men, or armour.
muthologie (g) expounding of the tales of the Poets.
§ micher, a ſtreaking fellow, a hedge créeper.
myſterie (g) a ſecret, or hid thing.
myſticall (g) that hath a miſterie in it.

list.head: N
list.item: nationall, belonging, or conſiſting of a nation, or kingdome.
natiue, where one was borne, or naturall.
natiuitie, birth, or the day of birth.
nauigable, where ſhips may ſafely paſſe, or that may be ſayled vpon.
nauigation, ſayling, or paſſing by water.
nauſeous, l • athing or diſpoſed to vomit.
necromancie (g) blacke art, or coniuring, by calling vpon ſpirits
nectar, a pleaſant drincke, which is feyned to bée drunke of the Gods.
§ nephew, a ſonne or daughters ſonne.
nicholaitan (g) an heretike, like Nicholas, who held that wiues ſhould bée common to all alike.
§ nonage, a childs time, vnder age.
nonreſidencie, vnneceſſary & wilful abſcence of any one from his place or charge.
§ nonſuite, not following, or the ending & giuing ouer of a ſuite.
notable, worthy, méete to be regarded and eſtéemed.
notifie, to make knowne, or to giue warning of.
notorious, knowne to all, and made plaine and manifeſt.

list.head: O
list.item: Obdurate, harden, or to make more hard § obeiſance, obedience.

obiect, laide, or ſet againſt, or that whereon any thing reſteth, or that wherein
any thing is occupyed, or ſet a worke.
obſeruant, dutifull, full of diligent ſeruice.
obſolete, olde, paſt date, growne out of vſe or cuſtome.
obſtinate, froward, ſtubborne, or ſtiffe in his owne opinion.
obteſtate, humbly to beſéech, or to call to witneſſe.
§ occurrences, occaſions, things that offer themſelues by the way.
oeconomicke (g) things that pertaine to houſhold affaires.
offenſiue, giuing offence, offering wrong, or diſpleaſing.
officious, dutifull, diligent, very readie or willing to pleaſe.
oligarchie (g) a Common-wealth where the gouernment is vnder a few perſons.
§ ombrage, ſhade, harbor, or bower to reſt vnder.
ominous, that ſignifieth • ome good, or ill lucke.
opinionate, hauing a good opinion of, or ſtanding on his owne opinion.
oppoſite, contrary, or ſet ouer againſt.
opprobrious, reprochfull, to taunt, reuile or vpbraid with bad ſpéeches.
oppugne, to labour againſt, or reſiſt.
oracle (g) a ſpéech or anſwere giuen from God.
orifice, mouth, or hole of any thing.
originall, the firſt, or ſuch as it was at the beginning.
organe (g) an inſtrument to doe any thing with.
ornament, a decking, adorning, or trimming

list.head: P
list.item: page, the ſide of a leaſe.
§ palatine, belonging to a Princes Court, or pallace.
palinodie (g) a recanting, or vnſaying of any thing.
§ palliſade, a place encloſed with pales.
palpable, that may be felt, manifeſt.
pamphlet, a ſmall treatiſe, or booke.
pander, a man baude to a whore.
parable (g) ſimilitude, or an applying of ſome thing to our matter, fi • ly alleaged, for ſome likeneſſe which it hath to our purpoſe.
paradoxe (g) marua •• o • s, or ſtrange ſpéech.
paralelles (g) lines, or other things as farre off from one another, in one place as in another.
paraphraſe (g) expoſition of any thing by many words.
paraſite (g) a baſe flatterer, or ſoothing companion.
parentheſis (g) a clauſe contained in another ſentence.
participate, partake deuide, or diſtribute, to giue, or take part.
particularize, to deuide into parts, and to handle euery particular.
paſſeable, that may be paſſed ouer.

paſſeouer, one of the Iewes Feaſts, in remembrance of Gods paſſing ouer them,
when he flew ſo many of the Egiptians.
patheticall (g) vehement, full of paſſions or mouing affections.
patrimonie, fathers gift, or goods left by a father.
pectorall, that belongeth to the breaſt.
§ pelmell, confuſedly, all on a heape.
§ pedant, one that hath the ouerſight of children.
penitentiarie, one repenting, or doing pennance.
perch, ſit vpon a pole or branch.
peregrination, iournying in a ſtrange land.
period (g) the end of a perfect ſentence.
periurie, forſwearing, or breaking of ones oath.
permanent, continuing, or abiding till the end.
perſecute, trouble, afflict, or purſue after.
perſiſt, perſeuer, continue, conſtantly, and reſolutely.
perſpicuous, euident, cléere, that may bée ſéene through.
peruert, ouerthrow, or turne vpſide downe.
pettilaſſerie, ſtealing of things of no great value.
phylacteries (g) ſcroles of parchment, wheron was written the ten commandments.
phyſiognomie (g) knowledge of a mans nature by his viſage, and countenance.
§ pillage, ſpoile in war, and ſacking of the enimies.
§ pilot, maiſter, guider of a ſhip.
piramis (g) piramides, a ſtéeple, or other building, or a pillar broad beneath, and ſharpe aboue.
§ pirate, a robber on the ſea.
platforme, the mould & faſhion of an houſe.
plauſible, pleaſing or receiued ioyfully, and willingly.
§ plonge, dip, or put vnder the water.
pole (g) the end of the axetrée wheron the aſtronomers fain the heauens to be turned.
poligamie, (g) hauing moe wines then one.
poliſh, to deck, or make faire, ſmooth, •• éeke, or ſhining.
pollute, deſtle, or diſtaine, or make filthy.
pompe, the countenance of things in furniture, & ſetting forth to the outward ſhew.
popular, ſéeking the • auour of the people by all meanes poſſible.
poſition, a queſtion to be diſp •• ſed of.
poſteritie, they that come after by birth, the age after vs.
§ pourtraie, draw the forme, or proportion of a thing.
§ preamble, foreſpéech, a flowriſh, entrance, or aſſay.
precept, a rule giuen, an admonition, or commandement.
predeceſſor, one that was in place before another.
preheminence, excellencie, rule, authoritie ouer others.
preface, a ſpéech before the matter it ſelfe.
prefixed, ſet in the forepart appointed before

preiudicate, giuing his iudgement, before
he knoweth the man, or matter.
preiudice, hindering ones cauſe, ſentence, or opinion deliuered before knowledge of any thing.
preludium, an entrance to any thing.
premeditation, thinking of a matter before hand.
preoccupation, a preuenting by ſpéech or other wayes.
preparatiue, that which maketh ſit or prepareth.
prepoſterous, diſordered, froward, topſituruy, ſetting the cart before the horſe, as we vſe to ſay.
prerogatiue, priuiledge, or authoritie before another.
preſage, to tell before, to betoken, to foreſée.
preſcription, limitation, or appointing a certaine compaſſe.
preſident, a chiefe ruler next vnder the higheſt.
preſuppoſe, ſaine a thing to be before it is.
pretermit, to paſſe ouer, to forget willingly.
preuarication, colluſion, or betraying of a cauſe or matter, for want of more earneſt ſpéech.
primitiue, primarie, firſt, or formoſt, or excellent.
prioritie, being in the formoſt place, or in greater excellencie and ſuperioritie then another.
priuation, depriuing, vtter taking away. or withdrawing.
priuiledge, prerogatiue, or liberty, more then others haue.
probable, that may be eaſilie proued to bée true.
probleme (g) propoſition, or ſentence, in manner.
proceede, goe forth, or goe forward.
prodigall, too rio • ous in ſpending.
prodigious, wonderfull, giuing an ill ſigne.
profane, vngodly, not conſecrated, or vnhallowing that which was holy.
progenie, o •• pring, generation, or iſſue of children.
prognoſticate (g) to know or giue out before hand, or to tell afore hand what ſhal happen
prohibit, to forbid or giue ſtraight charge to 〈…〉 trary.
proiect, a plot, or wiſe contriuing of any thing, or caſting • orth.
promote, to honor, or aduance to greater dignitie and higher place.
promulgation, publiſhing openly, or pro • laiming.
pronowne, that is ſet for the name of a thing
propitiation, a ſacrifice to appeaſe Gods diſpleaſure.
propitiatorie, that which recōcileth, or which purchaſeth mercy, at the mercy ſeate.
propoſe, propound, ſet before or ſhew.
proprietie, propertie, owing or challenging as his owne, and none others.
proſcription, a condemnation, or baniſhment proclaimed, or an open ſale.
proſe, that writing which is not verſe.
proſelite (g) ſtranger conuerted to our religion and manners.
proſpect, a ſight a farre off.
proſtitute, ſet open for vncleanneſſe, to ſet foorth to ſale.
proſtrate, to caſt downe, or fall downe flat on the ground.
proteſt, to affirme, or declare openly.
protract, deferre, or prolong, or draw out at length.
prouident, foreſéeing with wiſe conſideration, and prouiding aforehand.
prouinciall, iuriſdiction, belonging to a prouince, or out country.
prouocation, prouoking, enforcing, vrging, preſſing or alluring.
publicane, a farmer, or cōmon man of a citie
puluiriſated, b • aten, or broken into duſt, or powder.
pupill, that is vnder a tutor, a ward.
purifie, purge, ſcoure, or make cleane.
putrifie, to waxe rotten, or corrupt as a ſore.

list.head: Q
list.item: quadrant, quadrate, foure ſquare, or a quarter.
quartane, belonging to, or comming euery fourth day.
queaſie, weake, ſéeble, not well digeſting.
querimonious, full of complaining and lamentation.
§ quinteſſence, chiefe vertue, drawne by art out of many compounds together.
quotidian, daily, that happeneth euery day.

list.head: R
list.item: RAcha, fle, a note of extreame anger, ſignified by the geſture of the perſon, that ſpeaketh it, to him that he ſpeaketh to.
radicall, pertayning to the roote, naturall.
§ rallie, gather together men diſperſed, and out of order.
rapacitie, rapine, violent taking away, extorcio • or pillage, or rauening.
§ raunged, ordered, or put in order.
reall, ſubſtantiall, or that is indéed ſubſiſting
recantation, an vnſaying of that which was before ſaid.
recapitulation, a briefe rehearſing againe of any thing.
receptacle, a place to receiue things in.
reciprock, or reciprocall, that hath reſpect backe againe to the ſame thing.
reclaime, to gainſay, or call back againe.
§ recogniſſance, acknowledging, or a ſigne of acknowledging, and confeſſing any thing.
reconcile, bring into fauour, or to make peace betwixt.
records, writings laid vp for remembrance.
rectifie, to make right or ſtraight.
redeeme, purchaſe, buy againe, or ranſome.
redundant, ouerflowing, or abounding too much.
reeſtabliſh, to ſettle againe as before.
refell, to confute, or proue falſe.
reference, a pointing at, or alluding to.
referre, put ouer, or, to report himſelfe vnto.
reflection, caſting backe, or • owing, turning backe againe.
refuge, ſuccour, or place of ſafetie.
regiment, gouernment, guidance, rule, or dominion.
regrator, huckſter, or one that buyeth any thing, and trims it vp to make it more ſalable.
regular, made according to rule and order.
reiect, fling, caſt away or re • uſe.
§ reioynder, a thing added afterward, or is when the defendant maketh anſwere to the replication of the plaintife.
reiterate, to doe or repeate againe the ſame thing often.
remarkable, able or worthy to be marked againe.
remiſſe, looſe, negligent, or dull, or too fauourable
repell, to put or thruſt back.
repercuſsiue, ſtriking or rebounding backe againe.
repleueying, redéeming of a gage, or any thing in priſon.
replie, to confirme a ſpéech before vttered.
repreſent, expreſſe, • eare ſhew of a thing.
repreſſe, put downe, to let or ſtop.
reprobate, a caſt away, out of fauour, a forlorne perſon, and one paſt grace.
repugne, to re 〈…〉 oppoſe, ſtand againſt.
repulſe, to put or driue back, alſo denyall.
reſerue, to kéepe for the time to come.
reſident, abiding or continuing in his place
reſignation, a yéelding vp, or reſtoring of any thing.
reſolue, to vnlooſe, to ſatiſfie, to purpoſe conſtantly.
§ reſpite, defer, delay the time to breath in.
reſtrained, being helo in, or bridled.
§ retire, to giue backe, or go back.
retort, to turne, or wreſt backward.
reueale, lay open, diſcloſe, or make knowne a matter of ſecret.
reuiſe, to looke on, or read againe.
reuoke, to call backe, or draw back.
§ reuolt, forſake one, to goe to another his enimie.
reuolution, turning back to the ſame place.
reuolue, to toſſe vp and downe, to determine well of in the minde.
rhume (g) a diſtilling of humours from the head.
ridiculous, that deſerueth to bée laughed at in ſcorne.
§ riffle, ſearch, take away by violence.
§ rinſe, waſh, make cleane by waſhing.
§ riuall, one ſuing, and ſtriuing for the ſame thing that another • oth.
ruminate, to chew ouer againe, to ſtudie earneſtly vpon.
runnagate, one that runneth away, and wandreth abroad.
rurall, ruſticall, clowniſh, vplandiſh, or churliſe and vnmannerly.

list.head: S
list.item: ſacrament, holy ſigne, oath, or myſteri • .
ſacriledge, church robbing, the ſtealing of holy things.

§ ſafeconduit,
• a • e kéeping or ſafe guiding.
§ ſallie, to ſtep out from the reſt of the army, to make a ſkirmiſh.
ſanctifie, hallow, make holy, or kéepe holy.
ſanguine, bloudy, or of the colour of bloud.
ſatisfaction, a making amends for wrongs, or diſpleaſures.
ſatisfactorie, that diſchargeth, or anſwereth for.
ſatyre (g) a nipping and ſcoffing verſe.
ſatericke, belonging to a ſcoffing verſe.
ſcandalize (g) to • ffend, or giue occaſion to miſlike.
ſcandall (g) an offence, or ſtumbling block.
§ ſcarifie, to launce, or open a ſore.
§ ſcedule, obligation, or bill of ones hand, alſo a briefe.
ſchiſme (g) breach, or diuiſion in matters of religion.
ſeclude, ſhut out, or put a part.
ſectarie, one whom many other doe follow in opinion
ſect, a diuerſitie in opinion from others.
ſecundarie, the ſecond, or of the ſecond ſort.
ſediment, that which ſinketh to the bottome.
ſeduce, deceiue, or deuide, or leade aſide.
ſegregate, to ſet a part, or ſeperate.
§ ſeize, to forfaite to the prince, alſo to lay hold on.
ſelect, to chooſe out from others.
ſemicircle, halfe a circle or compaſ • e.
ſeminarie, a nurſerie, or ſéede plot for young trées, or grafts.
ſenſuall, brutiſh, per • aining to the fleſh, and bodily ſenſe.
ſententious, full of fine ſentences, & ſpéeches
ſeperation, deuiding, ſeuering, or parting one from another.
ſequele, following or that which followeth
ſequeſter, to put into an indifferent mans hands, to diuide, kéepe or iudge of.
ſerious, earneſt or of waight, & importance.
ſerpentine, of, or like a ſerpent.
ſignificant, plainely ſignifying, or ſhewing by tokens.
ſimilie, or ſimilitude, likeneſſe, or reſemblance.
§ ſimonie, when ſpirituall matters, are bought, and ſold for money.
ſiniſter, vnhappy, bad, vnlawful, or contrary
ſincere, pure, vncorrupt, vnmingled, or without diſſimulation.
ſingularitie, a being like no body elſe, in opinion, or other wayes.
ſituation, ſetting, or ſtanding of any place.
ſmatterer, ſomewhat learned, or one hauing but a little ſkill.
ſociall, or ſociable, fellow like, one that will kéepe company, or one with whom a may eaſily keepe company.
ſodometrie, when one man lyeth filthylie with another man.
ſolemnize, to doe a thing with great pomp, reuerence, or deuotion.
ſoluble, looſe in body, going often to ſtoole.
ſolſticke, when the Sunne is at the higheſt or loweſt.
ſophiſtication, ſophiſme, a cauilling, deceitfull ſpéech.
§ ſoueraigne, chiefe, or higheſt in authority.
§ ſource, waue, or iſſuing forth of water.
ſpa • ious, large, wide or broad.
ſpectacle, a thing to be looked at.
ſphaere (g) round circle, or any thing that is round.
ſpicerie, a place to kéepe ſpice in.
ſpleniticke, that is ſicke of the ſplene.
ſtabliſhed, ſure, confirmed, or made ſtrong.
ſtatue, an image of woode, or any other matter.
ſteward, ſtéed-man, the kéeper of the place.
ſtigmaticall (g) knauiſh, noted for a lewde naughtie fellow, burnt through the eare for a rogue.
ſtile, manner or forme of ſpéech, or writing
ſtipendarie, one that ſerueth for wages.
ſtratageme, a pollicie or wittie ſhift in war.
ſtrangurie (g) making of water with great paine and very hardly.
ſtructure, building, ſetting in good order.
ſubalterne, ſuccéeding, following by courſe and order.
ſubdued, kept vnder or brought into ſubiection.
ſubiugate, ſubdue, bring vnder the yoake.
ſubli • e, ſet on high, lift vp.
ſubmiſſe, lowly, humble, brought in ſubiection.
ſubſcribe, write vnder, or to agrée with another in any matter.
ſubſidiarie, that is giuen or ſent to aide another.
ſ • bſiſt, to abide or haue a being.
ſubſtitute, a deputie or one ſet in place of an other.
ſubuert, to turne vpſide downe, to deſtroy.
ſucceede, follow, to come in anothers place.
ſucceſſor, he that comes in place of another
ſuccinct, ſhort or briefe or cloſe girt vp.
ſuggeſt, prompt, tell priuilie or put in mind of.
ſuffocate, to choake vp, ſtrangle or ſtop the breath.
ſuffragane, a Biſhops deputie, or helper.
ſuffrage, conſent, or voyce or helpe.
ſuggeſt, to put in minde, to tell.
§ ſummarie an abridgement or thing drawn into a leſſe compaſſe.
ſupererogation, giuing more then is required.
ſuperabundant, ſuperfluous, néedeleſſe, vnneceſſarie, ouer much, that which runneth ouer.
ſuperficiall, belonging to the outſide and vppermoſt part.
ſupernaturall, beyond the order of nature.
ſupernall, from aboue, that is one high.
ſuperſtitious, fearefull in matters of religion without cauſe, one giuen • o falſe and vaine religion.
ſupplant, ouerthrow, or trip with the foote, roote out.
ſupplement, that which maketh vp, or addeth that which wanteth in any thing.
ſupport, beare vp, or conuay vnder.
ſuppoſition, ſuppoſing, thinking, iudging, or imagining.
ſuppreſſe, kéepe downe, conceale, or kéepe
ſupremacie, chiefedome, or higheſt place in authoritie aboue all others.
§ ſurceaſe, to giue ouer, or ceaſe.
§ ſurmount, § ſurpaſſe, éede, or goe beyond.
§ ſurpriſe, to come vpon vnawares, and to take of a ſuddaine.
§ ſurrender, to yéeld vp to another.
§ ſurrogate, a deputie in anothers place.
§ ſuruiue, ouer liue, or liue after.
ſuture, a ſeame, or ioyning together.
ſycophant (g) tale bearer or falſe accuſer.
ſymm- • rie (g) a due proportion of one part with another.
ſymphonie, harmonie and conſent in tune.
ſymptome (g) any grief or paſſion following a diſeaſe.
ſynode (g) a generall aſſembly or méeting.
ſyntaxe (g) conſtruction and order of words.

list.head: T
list.item: § tapiſh, lye downe, hide it ſelfe.
taxed, ſeiſed, appointed to pay a ſubſidie.
temperature, temperament, temperateneſſe, meane, or due proportion.
temporall, that which indureth but for a certaine time.
temporiſe, to ſerue the time or to follow the faſhion and behauiour of the time.
§ tenure, hold, or manner of holding a poſſeſſion.
tergiuerſation, going back, or leauing a ſute.
§ territorie, region, or the country, lying about the citie.
tertian, belonging to euery third day.
tetrach (g) gouernour, or prince of a fourth part of a country.
theater, a common place of playes & ſhowes.
theme (g) matter propoſed to be written or ſpoken of.
theologie (g) diuinitie, the ſcience of holy things.
theorie (g) the contemplation, or inward knowledge of any art.
throne (g) a Kings ſeate, or chaire of eſtate.
thro • le, ſtrangle, hang, or • orment.
tincture, a colour, dye, or ſtayning.
tollerable, that which may bée •• ffered.
tone (g) a tune, note, or accent.
§ trace, finde out by the foote ſteps.
tractable, eaſie to handle, or eaſily entreated.
〈◊〉 , a treatiſe, or booke, handling any (matter.
traduce, to ſlander, reproach, or defame, to bring in, or draw from one to another.
tragèdian, a maker, or player of a tragedie.
tragedie (g) a ſolemne play, deſcribing cruell murders and ſorrowes.
tragicall, cruell, ſorrowfull like a tragedie.
tranquilitie, quietneſſe, or calmnes, or reſt.
transforme, transfigure, change from one faſhion, to another.
tranſgreſſe, breake, offend, or goe ouer.
tranſition, paſſing from one thing to another
§ tranſitorie, ſoone paſſing away, not long laſting.
tranſmigration, a paſſing from one place to dwell in another.
tranſmutation, a change from one place, to another.
tranſparent, that which may be ſéen through.
tranſport, carry ouer, from one place to another.
tranſpoſe, change, or ſet out of order.
tranſubſtantiation, a changing of one ſubſtance into another.
traue, a place to ſhoe wild horſes in.
tribe, a company, ward, or hundred.
treſſes, lockes of hayre broyded vp.
triobolar, little worth, of no eſtimation.
tripartite, thréefold, or de • ided into thrée parts.
trophee, a victory, or any thing ſet in ſigne of victory.
tropickes (g) circles in the heauen which when the Sunne comes to, begins to returne againe.
§ troupe, company, or band of men in an armie.
truculent, cruell, or terrible in countenance.
tumult, vprore, hurly burly, or inſurrection.
tumultuous, turbulent, troublous, diſturbing, or diſquieting.
type (g) figure, example, ſhadow of any thing.

list.head: V
list.item: vacation, a time of ceaſing from labor.
§ vagabond, runnagate, one that will ſtay no where.
§ vanquiſh, ouercome, preuaile, conquere, or ouerthrow.
vapor, moiſture, aire, hot breath, or reaking.
§ vantgard, the forefront of an army.
vbiquitie, preſence of a perſon in all places.
varniſh, ſhine, ſet a gloſſe vpon.
vegetable, ſpringing, or growing as hearbs.
vendible, ſaileable, eaſie & readie to be ſolde.
veneriall, venerous, fleſhly, or lecherous, giuen to lecherie.
veniall, that which may bée pardoned.
ventricle, the ſtomack whichreceiues yt meai
§ verger, one that beares a ſiluer rodde in our cathedrall Churches.
verifie, to proue to bée true.
vertigiouſnes, lightnes, or a ſwimming of the head.
veſture, veſtiment, garment, attire, or clothing.
§ viceroy, one ſet as a deputie in the Kings place.
vicegerent, one that ſupplyeth the place of another.
vicious, faultie, or full of vice.
victorious, that hath gotten many victoryes.
viewe, behold, marke, or conſider, or looke vpon.
vincible, that may be wonne, or eaſily ouercome.
violate, to tranſgreſſe, defile, deflowre or breake.
viperine, like a viper, or of a viper.
virago, a woman of a manly courage.
viſion, ſight, apparition, or a phantaſie.
vitall, liuely, or pertayning to life.
vi • ate, to corrupt, or deſtower, and defile.
viuificent, liuely, or full of ſtrength.
viuifie, to quicke • , or make aliue.
vlcerate, to bliſter, or make full of • ores.
vnconceaueable, not able to be conceiued.
vnacceſsiuely, that cannot bée come to.
vnanimitie, one conſent of hart and minde.
vnguent, an oyntment, or fat iuyce.
vnitie, to make one thing of two, or moe, to couple, or ioyne.
vniformitie, one and the ſame faſhion.
vocall, with the voyce, or pertayning to the voyce.
vocation, calling, eſtate, or trade of life.
vnſatiable, that neuer hath inough, neither can bée ſatiſfied.
vnweldie, not able to moue, lumpiſh.
voluntarie, of the owne accord, without being taught, or vrged.
§ vpbraid, riſe in ones ſtomack, caſt in ones teeth.
vrbanitie, curteſie, good manners, or gentleneſſe.
vrine, water of man or beaſt.
§ vſurpe, take vnlawfull authoritie, or to vſe againſt right and reaſon.
§ vtenſiles, things neceſſary for our vſe in houſe-kéeping, or in a trade.

list.head: Y
list.item: ye • ne, deſire, take griefe, alſo to deſerue.

list.head: Z
list.item: ZEale (g) earneſt deſire to a thing.
zodiack (g) a circle in the heauen, wher in bée placed the 12. Signes, and in which the Sunne is moued.
Zonet (g) circles in the heauens, deuiding the world into fiue parts.
